utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Um, what brings you in today?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh yeah, hi, I just came in here today cause uh, lately, for the last couple of months, I've been getting these coughing fits. They don't really seem to be going away and I was a bit concerned.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: So you've had this, when did this start?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, I would say probably during the winter uh it, it kind of started, where I started having um, just coughing fits when I'm walking to school and then also during like gym class I started having these coughing fits and sometimes I also felt like I couldn't breathe.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Um, okay. Okay, what did you, is there anything, so it's basically worse when you're um, doing some sort of an exercise such as walking um, or being in the gym class, and it's also worse in the cold?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah. Yeah, and then also like, I remember when I was walking down the street and someone was smoking and then I just completely just started having that episode right after I walked past them.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay um, alright. Uh um okay, sorry, one moment. Okay um, so is there anything that makes your cough better? What do you do to make it go away?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, I just basically have to, if I, if I'm doing any kind of activities, just take a moment, sit down for like 10 to 15 minutes and then it seems like it goes away on its own.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And you said that sometimes you also have difficulties breathing with it?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, like a couple of times it got really bad where I had to um like, it was difficult get, it was, it was like I was trying to take deep breaths for air, but uh it was, it just felt like I couldn't.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: I see. So this started a couple of months ago, has this ever happened to you before that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, before that I've been fine.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, and so I'm going to ask you about a couple other symptoms. Let me know if you've experienced any of these in the past couple of months. Um, so have you had a headache that accompanies the cough?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Um, any changes in your vision or your hearing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any confusion?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Um any, um, runny nose or stuffy nose or sinus congestion?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no, not really.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, any sore throat?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any um, chest pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, sometimes when I get like really bad coughing fits, like it sometimes starts hurting in my chest as well.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah. Um, does it go away when you stop coughing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, it goes away after, I just take some rest.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Um, have you had any belly pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no, not at all.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Do you feel like your heart's racing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any changes in your, any nausea or vomiting?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any changes in your bowel movements?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any acid reflux?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, um, and any certain muscle aches or joint pains?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um no, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any numbness or tingling in your arms or legs?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, let's get back. Okay, great, it sounds like that the, the cough is sort of the main symptom here that you have. Um, is the cough dry or wet?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It's usually uh, it's usually dry.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Uh sorry, can you say that again?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It's usually dry.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay um, have you ever brought up any sputum or any blood?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh never any blood, I have like on occasion, like sometimes brought up some sputum.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, alright. Um okay, and, uh, have you been vaccinated?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, yeah, all my immunizations are up to date.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, good good good. Um, does the cough sound like a barky cough or a muffled cough, or um, does it have a specific characteristic? Does it sound different than when you're sort of coughing to clear your throat, for instance?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh yeah, it's like pretty, it can get pretty harsh. I also noticed like uh, there's like this weird noise I started making like right after when I'm trying to take deep breaths in.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, okay. Okay, so you're wheezing. Okay, so you ever um, cough so much that you end up vomiting?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no that hasn't happen yet.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Um, and do you, so you mentioned that it's worse when you're in the cold or exercising, and smoking makes it worse? What about things like dust or pollen? Um, say when you're cleaning the house and there's also dust, does that make things worse, or is it worse in a specific time of the year when you're outdoors?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, now that you mention it, yeah, like if we're ever in the basement or anything like that, I, I do start getting like kind of irritation um, in my throat, and that kind of, sometimes I have also coughed at those times.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright. Uh, can you tell me, okay so, can you tell me if you have any medical conditions that you've been diagnosed with?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing else, I've been pretty healthy.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay. Had, did, when you were a child, did you have any sort of rash? Did you have eczema?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Oh I, yeah, so I did I, at one point I was using like this cream um, probably when I was ten. Just for some eczema on my hands.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay. And um, have you ever had allergic rhinitis, which is basically sort of having um, red or teary eyes, itchiness on the face, a runny nose at certain times of the year, or in um, areas with mold or dust, or termites and things like that? Have you had anything like that as a child or right now?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, not that I know of, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay. Alright, uh do you have any, um, I guess going back, were you a healthy child, growing up?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, as far as I know, I, I didn't really have any concerns from like the school or home at all.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, that's great. Do you uh, did you ever have any hospitalizations?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any surgeries?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Are you taking any medications?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no medications.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Are you still using the eczema cream?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no. That kind of just went away on its own, or like right after I used the cream. Like it's good now.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, good. Are you allergic to anything?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I don't think so. Maybe just like environmental allergies sometimes, in the springtime.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: What happens then?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, just sometimes like uh, I don't know if it's like a pollen allergy like I, I do get some, I guess I do get like some nasal congestion and things like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Um, have you ever seen an allergist?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I haven't.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No. Uh, who prescribed the cream for the eczema?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, just a, it was like at a walk-in clinic.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, okay. Um alright, and do you have any family history of any um, lung-related problems? Or any other problems?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, my older sister has asthma, and uh, I don't know if anyone else in the family has asthma. Um, I think my father has high blood pressure.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, and you mentioned that things are going well at school. Um, who do you live with at home?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah so I live with my older sister, and my mom and dad.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, okay. And things are good at home? Do you feel safe?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, yeah, I feel completely safe.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any concerns about bullying at school?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no, not at all.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay are you uh, are you taking any marijuana or any street drugs?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no, my parents would kill me.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: What about alcohol?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, I'll come, I've, I haven't tried it um, yet, at all.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, okay. Just wanted to mention that the conversation that we're having right now is confidential between you and me. Um, unless you mentioned anything that harms you or harms anyone else so, so feel free to discuss whatever or talk openly about um, any issues that you have. Um, okay, and um, are you sexually active?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, okay. So um, that's all the information I needed. Uh given that you've had these coughing fits for the past couple of months that are, that have certain triggers, uh, and also given that you've had a history of eczema, and your sister has asthma, so kind of, sort of runs in your family in a way. You might also have a diagnosis of asthma potentially. Um, and so, what I would recommend is that you get um, testing done and um, uh I guess before I sort of talk a little more about this, I just want to get a sense of how severe your asthma, if it's asthma at all, um if, does it, does it affect your ability to, you said school was going okay, does it affect your ability to do well at school at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um definitely in, in gym class, but other than that it hasn't really affected me.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Does it wake you up at night?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, so far no. I, I like, I get pretty good sleep.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, okay. Um, and how often, I guess is, do these episodes occur? How many times a week, or how many times a month?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, so they just started like two months ago, and I've had like maybe four or five of them in total.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, okay. Uh, and they kind of get better on their own. Okay, so we can sort of talk about these, sorry, puffers that you might need to, to use as needed. Um, your sister might have some of those, so you might be familiar with what I'm talking about.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Um, so we can talk about that. Um, given that your symptoms are, yes, they've been occurring for the past couple of months, but because you have had a cough, it might be a good idea just to have a COVID test done once. Um, I don't think that's what you have, seeing that this, these symptoms have been lasting for, have been occurring for the past two months, so we'll just kind of do that test to rule it out. Um, in the meantime, I would recommend that you um, try this inhaled corticosteroid puffer that you can use, that you should use on a daily basis, and try to avoid uh, the triggers. So the things that you, that cause these symptoms. Um, we can go over how to use uh, a puffer properly and I will also give you a spacer, which will help deliver most of that medication in the, uh, to your lungs. Do you have any questions?

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Add differential diagnosis
